lessons.title: Understanding Integers
lessons.content: Integers are whole numbers that can be positive, negative, or zero. They are used to represent quantities that can be counted or measured.

examples.problem: Represent 5 degrees above zero using an integer
solution: Step 1: Understand that temperatures above zero are represented by positive integers
Step 2: Represent 5 degrees above zero as +5

examples.problem: Represent 3 degrees below zero using an integer
solution: Step 1: Understand that temperatures below zero are represented by negative integers
Step 2: Represent 3 degrees below zero as -3

quiz.text: What is the integer representation of 2 degrees below zero?
What is the integer representation of 10 degrees above zero?
Which of the following is an integer?

lessons.title: Operations with Integers
lessons.content: When performing operations with integers, we need to consider the rules for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing positive and negative numbers.

solution: Step 1: Understand that adding a positive number is the same as moving to the right on the number line
Step 2: Start at -3 and move 5 steps to the right to get 2
Step 1: Subtracting a negative is the same as adding a positive

lessons.title: Introduction to Fractions
lessons.content: Fractions represent parts of a whole. The numerator shows how many parts we have, and the denominator shows how many parts make up the whole.

solution: Step 1: Find the greatest common divisor of 6 and 8, which is 2
Step 2: Divide both numerator and denominator by 2: 6÷2 = 3, 8÷2 = 4

lessons.title: Percentages – Calculations, Increase/Decrease, Discounts
lessons.content: Percentages represent parts out of 100. We use them to calculate discounts, increases, and decreases in real-life scenarios.

lessons.title: Factors & Multiples – LCM, HCF
lessons.content: Factors are numbers that divide exactly into another number. Multiples are numbers you get by multiplying by integers. LCM is the smallest common multiple. HCF is the largest common factor.

lessons.title: Square Numbers & Square Roots
lessons.content: Square numbers are numbers multiplied by themselves. The square root is the inverse operation, finding a number that when squared gives the original number.

lessons.title: Exponents / Powers – Basics
lessons.content: Exponents represent repeated multiplication of a number by itself. a^n means multiply a by itself n times.

lessons.title: Fractions – Multiplying & Dividing
lessons.content: Multiplying fractions: multiply numerators and denominators. Dividing fractions: multiply by reciprocal.

lessons.content: Performing multiplication and division with decimals, and estimating results.

lessons.content: Angles are formed when two rays meet at a point called the vertex. Learn types of angles and how to measure them.

lessons.title: Understanding Ratios
lessons.content: A ratio compares two or more quantities showing how many times one value contains another. Ratios can be written in different forms: fraction form (a/b), colon form (a:b), or word form ('a to b'). Understanding ratios helps us compare quantities and solve real-world problems involving proportional relationships.

lessons.title: Equivalent Ratios and Simplifying
lessons.content: Equivalent ratios express the same relationship between quantities. To find equivalent ratios, multiply or divide both terms by the same number. Simplifying ratios means finding the smallest whole numbers that express the same relationship by dividing both terms by their greatest common factor (GCF).

lessons.title: Solving Proportions
lessons.content: A proportion is an equation that states that two ratios are equal. The general form is a/b = c/d (where b ≠ 0, d ≠ 0). We solve proportions using cross multiplication: multiply diagonally across and solve for the unknown. Proportions are useful for solving real-world problems involving rates, scale, and comparisons.

examples.problem: A car travels 150 km in 3 hours. How far will it travel in 5 hours at the same speed?
solution: Step 1: Set up proportion: distance/time = 150/3 = x/5

quiz.text: A car travels 120 km in 2 hours. How far in 5 hours?
